title: Gang who used cattle prods and Tasers to guard brothel empire jailed
text:
The London criminal network made £1,000,000 a year from drugs and prostitutes (Picture: Met Police)

A criminal network who made £1 million a year by exploiting women and selling drugs in brothels across north London have been put behind bars.

Ringleader Renato Saachi, 43, his wife Flavia Xavier-Sacchi, 23 and brother Raul Sacchi, 49, ran venues across the capital and spend their cash on luxury holidays, expensive cars and jewellery.

Their henchmen used cattle prods, Tasers, pepper spray, and baseball bats to protect the brothels.

Drugs and alcohol were sold from dens in Kensington High Street, Cricklewood, Queen’s Park, Kingsbury and Hanger Lane.

Scotland Yard launched a series of raids after a sex worker told police the gang had threatened to kill her family in Brazil after she tried to leave two months into her job.

Police found massive wads of cash in a series of raids (Picture: Met Police)

Ringleader Renato Sacchi, 43, was jailed for eight years and 11 months (Picture: Met Police)

After more than a year working undercover, officers raided brothels in Cricklewood, Broadway and Kenton Court and arrested Antonio Teca Miranda.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Police found 15 packets of cash and charts setting out the leadership structure of the gang.

Further probing led to the arrests of the Sachis, Maria Carvalho, 43, Keagan Boyd, 34, Tony Simao, 42, Henim Almeida, 25, and Anna Paula De Almeida Prudente, 21.

When police searched Renato and Flavia’s home in Hendon, northwest London, they found £50,000, two Tasers and a CS gas canister.

Detectives analysed encrypted messages on mobile phones seized from the group.

The gangsters spent their money on luxury cars and watches (Picture: Met Police)

Raul Sacchi, 49, said: ‘There is no such thing as tired girls. They’re there to work’ (Picture: Met Police)

In one group chat Raul Sacchi said: ‘There is no such thing as tired girls. They’re there to work.’

Him and his brother held separate conversations for their Wyndale Avenue and Norbreck Parade venues and for ‘security staff’.

Eight gang members were jailed for a total of 39 years at Harrow Crown Court on Thursday.

Renato Sacchi was jailed for eight years and 11 months after admitting to controlling prostitution for gain, conspiring to do so, being concerned in the supply of cocaine, and possessing a Taser and a CS Gas canister and criminal property.

His wife was convicted of similar Class A drug and prostitution charges and sentenced to eight years and seven months.

Raul Sacchi, from Soho, Central London, was jailed for nine years and six months imprisonment for his role in the supply of prostitutes and drugs.

Flavia Xavier-Sacchi helped keep Class A drugs flowing through their brothels (Picture: Met Police)

The gang guarded their venues with Tasers and cattle prods (Picture: Met Police)

Boyd, of no fixed address, admitted possession of a Taser and being concerned in the supply of Class A drugs and was jailed for two years and two months.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Almeida, of no fixed address, was convicted of controlling prostitution for gain, possession of a gas canister and Taser, being concerned in the supply of class A drugs and possession of criminal property.

He was sentenced to three years’ imprisonment.

Carvalho, of Kingsbury, northwest London, admitted to controlling prostitution for gain, possession of Class A drugs and possession of criminal property and was given a three year sentence.

Prudente, also from Kingsbury, admitted to supplying prostitutes as well as possession of criminal property.

She was sentenced to one year and two months imprisonment.

Miranda, of Edmonton, north London, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to control prostitution for gain, being concerned in the supply of cannabis and possession of criminal property.

Maria Carvalho, 43, was jailed for three years for her part in the enterprise (Picture: Met Police)

Antonio Teca Miranda was sentenced to two years and six months in prison (Picture: Met Police)

He was sentenced to two years and six months imprisonment.

Simao, of Peckham, south London, was convicted of being concerned in the supply of cocaine and possession of two Tasers and is yet to be sentenced.

Detective Inspector Dan Mitchell, who led the investigation, said: ‘This lengthy and complex investigation has dismantled an organised crime group who were exploiting women across London for their own financial gain.

‘Through thorough examination of their devices, detectives found the group saw themselves as a legitimate business which they went to extreme lengths to protect.

‘They employed and armed security guards and maintained control over all communication between their so-called employees.

Tony Simao, 42, is yet to be sentenced, having been convicted of helping supply cocaine and owning two Tasers (Picture: Met Police)

Henim Almeida, 25, was jailed for owning a gas canister, a Taser and drug and prostitution charges (Picture: Met Police)

‘Individuals often are reticent or too afraid to come forward in modern slavery investigations, so it is our job to build a prosecution and dismantle OCGs like this with whatever evidence we can.

Advertisement

‘Detectives spent months using a range of tactics to build a case against this group of criminals, taking an evidence-led approach, to ensure they were convicted and brought to justice.

‘Anyone considering exploiting other human beings for financial gain should expect to face the same level of expert investigation and prosecution.’

description: A London gang who sold Class A drugs and prostitutes in a brothel network across the capital were jailed at Harrow Crown Court.
